key_mistakes.reason: Black aims for the Caro-Kann but plays passively, allowing White to gain central control.
Capturing prematurely instead of maintaining central tension.
Develops the knight to c6 where it can be pinned by Bb5.
Castling into an already developed position, missing a more aggressive continuation.
Loses tempo with an unnecessary rook move, missing more active queen placement.
Misplaces the bishop without a clear plan.
Blunders material by allowing a knight to capture the queen.
Trades a knight for a pawn, missing a more effective attack on the bishop.
Returns the knight to an ineffective square, missing a tactical opportunity.
Misses the opportunity to improve the position of the rooks.
Relocates the queen to a passive position.
Blunders a knight, allowing opponent's knight to capture it.

recommendations: Focus on controlling the center with pawn moves like e4 and d4.
Develop pieces actively to squares where they can exert maximum influence.
Avoid unnecessary pawn captures that release central tension prematurely.
Be aware of tactical opportunities and threats, especially involving unprotected pieces.
